intro: Ranunculus rhodensis, commonly known as the Armenian buttercup, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus and parts of Turkey. It is characterized by its bright yellow flowers with five to eight petals, which bloom in early spring. The plant typically grows to a height of 20–40 centimeters and has palmate leaves with a hairy surface. It prefers well-drained soils and full sunlight, often found in rocky or alpine environments. Ranunculus rhodensis is valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes cultivated in gardens for its delicate appearance.
